headline: Suli: I still want to play for Australia and NSW before Tonga
author: Adam Pengilly
sentences:
If I get the chance to play for the Kangaroos, I’ll play there, and if not I’ll play for Tonga.”
The Pacific powerhouse is shaping as a legitimate threat to Mal Meninga’s Australia at the end of year World Cup in the United Kingdom, but Suli sees a potential future in the green gold with regular game time under his belt in the NRL.

The boys have been really welcoming and I’ve enjoyed every second of it so far.”
Dragons coach Anthony Griffin, known as a tough disciplinarian, has helped mould Suli into shape before St George Illawarra’s trials against the Eels and the Charity Shield match against the Rabbitohs.

Share
Normal text sizeLarger text sizeVery large text size
St George Illawarra recruit Moses Suli has set himself the ambitious goal of breaking into Brad Fittler’s NSW State of Origin team and declared his preference to play for Australia over Tonga in the World Cup.

It would seem an improbable task for Suli to displace arguably the NRL’s best player, Tom Trbojevic, and Latrell Mitchell from Fittler’s Blues centre pairing, but the 23-year-old insists Origin football is not out of the equation.

St George Illawarra Dragons recruit Moses Suli.Credit:St George Illawarra Dragons
Surprisingly, he played second fiddle behind centres Brad Parker and Morgan Harper last year as Manly charged into a preliminary final.

It was enough for the Dragons, who had long admired the powerful ball runner, to offer Suli a three-year deal at the Red V - forming a potentially lethal centre pairing with fellow Origin aspirant Zac Lomax.
Suli, who debuted for Mate Ma’a back in 2017, has broached his potentially career-defining switch to the Dragons, which came after he was starved of game time under Des Hasler at Manly last year.
Having already been in the systems of the Wests Tigers, Bulldogs, Sea Eagles and now Dragons before he has even turned 24, Suli knows this next phase will be crucial to his career.

I thought I was getting too comfortable at Manly and as you could see, I wasn’t playing much footy
Moses Suli
“I’m dying to play [Manly] and can’t wait.

Hopefully, I can play some finals footy here as well.”

“I thought I was getting too comfortable at Manly and as you could see, I wasn’t playing much footy last year.

By Adam Pengilly
 February 14, 2022 — 6.00pm

Suli expects to strip off even more weight before the season opener against the Warriors in Queensland.
As everyone knows, I went through a struggle in my first few years, but I’m a different person now.
“I’ve always wanted to play Origin and I’m still eligible for that,” Suli said.

I got injured and then was struggling to get my way back into the team.
“I’m about 109 [kilograms] and I want to lose a bit more,” Suli said.
“When I debuted I was 103 and I want to see if I can get down there.
But I just want to play any footy, I’m a bit sick of pre-season.
The boys were playing well and that made it hard for me.
I feel like this pre-season has been my best one so far.
I haven’t finished a full year without getting injured.
“To be honest, I just wanted a fresh start,” Suli said.
“I reckon I’ve matured heaps from my past few years.
This is the first full one I’ve done, though.
